A new method for synthesis of catalysts with core@shell architecture has been developed for syngas production via dry reforming of methane (DRM). This route is based on the confinement of Stöber particles (silica nanospheres) by nickel phyllosilicates and a layer-analogous decoration made of SiO2 (shell). Dry reforming catalysts based on non-noble metals suffer from deactivation via sintering and coke formation. Core@shell structures offer a strategy to enhance stability and control metal dispersion. In this work, the Stöber particles were obtained and then nickel phyllosilicate was synthetized over them (NiPS); silica was deposited on the resulting material producing a decorated material (S0@NiPS) and the effect of its aging under hydrolysis conditions for 12, 24, 36 and 48 h was evaluated (S12, S24, S36 and S48@NiPS). It was possible to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed structures, with reagent conversion above 90 %, good yield to syngas and no signs of deactivation in the catalytic test at 700°C (coking condition), for the S24@NiPS sample (reducible nickel content 8 % w/w). The superior activity of S24@NiPS is attributed to optimal Ni dispersion and shell structure, balancing accessibility and confinement. The order of activity obtained was: S24@NiPS > S12@NiPS > NiPS > S36@NiPS > S48@NiPS > S0@NiPS. The materials were characterized by XRD, TPR-H2, TPO-O2, TEM, EDS and TPSR-DRM. The modification of the hydrolysis time changed the properties of the catalysts: the shortest and longest times generated the less active catalysts. These findings offer a route to a coke-resistant catalysts for CO₂ valorization and methane upgrading. Energy production on an industrial scale to meet this demand is mainly based on fossil fuels (96 %), a non-renewable source that contributes significantly to the emission of greenhouse gases such as methane and carbon dioxide [1–3]. These emissions are linked to the successive climate changes observed since the Industrial Revolution, including melting glaciers and rising sea levels [4]. This is primarily due to the anthropogenic greenhouse effect produced by the gases aforementioned [5,6]. This scenario encourages the exploration of alternative green energy sources and the reutilization of greenhouse gases to mitigate their emission [7]. An example of such alternatives is the considerable effort to construct and consolidate CO2 capture facilities and invest in renewable energy sources (RESs) [6,8,9]. However, most of RESs are highly sensitive to seasonal and environmental factors [10], which lead to inevitable energetic disparities between energy production and demand during the year, whether positive or negative, suggesting that ways of storing this energy are needed for its adequate distribution and suitability [11–13]. The usage of these gases for the production of syngas, a mixture of CO and H2, may act as an essential ally on diminishing the dependency for fossil fuels, acting as alternative source of hydrocarbons from H2 and CO or as a way to store power in intermittent renewable energy sources in strategies known as Power-to-Fuel, mainly if carried on with CO2 from carbon capture facilities [7,14–17]. Among the various possible conversion forms, dry methane reforming (DRM) produces syngas with an H2:CO ratio of approximately 1, more suitable for industrial use than the approximately 3:1 ratio produced by steam methane reforming [1,2,16,18–20]. However, the high rate of deactivation of catalysts used in the dry reform reaction still impedes its application in an industrial context, so the topic has attracted research to counter it. Research has established catalysts with noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ru, Rh, etc.) as common due to their high activity and resistance to deactivation. Although less active and less resistant to coke formation, non-noble metals such as Co, Cu and Ni, cheaper and more accessible, are also studied for DRM [2,18,20–24]. Many strategies have been used to improve non-noble metal catalysts’ activity and resistance to deactivation, such as oxygen carriers, oxygen vacancy generation, different support materials and structures, such as core@shell catalysts [19,25–30]. Core@shell-type structures, that is, a structure based on layering different materials, generally at the nanoscale, may present various material combinations, such as inorganic@inorganic, inorganic@organic, organic@inorganic, or organic@organic [27,32]. The choice of material depends on the application and inorganic@inorganic materials are usually better suited due to DRM operation conditions. Especially those core@shell materials based on silica emerge in this context, presenting numerous properties that make this group of catalysts robust and efficient alternatives for producing syngas due to the possibility of structural tuning and improvement based on shell properties [25–30]. This is due to the possibility of nanotemplating, which controls porosity during shell formation [27,31], the ensemble effect, which can affect the energy levels of materials’ energy bands [31], and synergistic effects between the core and shell activities [30,32,33]. Furthermore, another property of these kinds of materials is the confinement effect that the shell provokes in structures inside them. That is due to mechanical processes, such as the initial states' destabilization due to spatial impediments [34], but also due to electronic effects, such as the population of antibonding orbitals by the shell species, which eases bond breaking [35]. Additionally, access control to active sites can suppress coke production, thereby improving the catalyst's resistance to deactivation [17,25,26,35,36]. The option for phyllosilicates can be linked to their structure, as their laminar structure tends to form material with high metal dispersion [26,36]. Phyllosilicates also tend to form networks with strong interactions between the silicon and the metal atoms, so that catalysts derived from them tend to have mitigated sintering deactivation, allowing for the attainment of highly dispersed and stable post-reduction Ni nanospheres (under 5 nm) [17,25,26,36]. For the core, silica nanospheres were utilized, and the synthesis method was Stöber’s. This method has many advantages, especially the obtention of well-defined monodisperse silica nanospheres with adjustable size relying on a straightforward experimental design [33,37]. This method consists of hydrolyzing tetraethyl-orthosilicate (TEOS) with ammonia in a water/alcohol medium, leading to the nucleation of silica nanoparticles [37,38]. The hydrolysis time, the proportion of water to ethanol, ammonia concentration, and TEOS concentration are all impactful factors in determining particle size and symmetry. Ammonia is reported to act as a catalyst for the TEOS hydrolysis reaction [37,39–41]. These particles are suitable candidates for catalyst support, as they rely on a simple procedure and produce high surface area materials due to nano-structuring. They can be doped with metals and oxides, forming core@shell structures [37]. A deposition strategy was developed by Majewski and Wood [42] for generating catalysts Ni@SiO2. Three-layered structures were also attempted in different works. Li and Sibudjing [43] designed a route for a multicore@NiPS@CeO2 using controlled hydrothermal and precipitation processes, promoting a high Ni dispersion and morphological shell control. The second layer can effectively fully encapsulate the inner structure, creating a sandwiched core@shell, or decorate its surface, creating an embedded structure around the Ni particles that mimics a second layer ( Fig. 1) [44]. Other works have worked with similar structures to the one proposed [45,46], but their emphasis was on structuring and comparing the layer effect, whereas the current work is interested in tuning the shell structure for optimizing the catalyst performance. Many studies have established that shell structuring is influenced by various factors [47,48]. But there is still a lack of studies comparing the aging time under hydrolysis conditions as a tuning parameter for bi-layered sandwiched material or analogous core@shell@shell structures, thus prompting this study to investigate the second shell formation and its development under hydrolysis conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of nickel phyllosilicates over nanospheres (NiPS) The catalysts were synthesized using a modified Stöber method, using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silicon source and NH4OH as the catalyst. The phyllosilicates were deposited according to the ammonia evaporation methodology, adapted from the literature [25,35,49]. The amount of TEOS used was estimated based on the resulting material mass, assuming that all silicon in TEOS is converted to SiO2. Initially, the TEOS was slowly added to a system of ethanol and water in a 5.6:1 volumetric ratio under slow stirring. Immediately after, concentrated ammonia was added until the pH reached 10, which took approximately the same molar amount of NH3 (aq). The mixture was kept under agitation for 24 h. Initially, the solution was translucent, but it became turbid after 1 h, indicating silica precipitation. After 24 h, nickel nitrate hexahydrate was added to the colloidal solution. The nitrate mass was calculated to ensure that the nickel mass was equal to 10 % of the catalyst's total mass. The pH was adjusted using concentrated ammonium hydroxide, which caused the solution to turn blue, likely due to the formation of hydroxy-nickel complexes [50]. The system was maintained at 60 ºC for 1 h to facilitate ammonia evaporation. This thermal treatment was visually accompanied by the system color changing back to green. At the end, the colloid was transferred to Falcon® tubes and centrifuged (2500 rpm, 5 min). The material obtained was then washed, dried and calcined at 700 °C (10 °C.min−1) for 4 h under a flow of 50 mL.min−1 of synthetic air. The resulting material is dubbed NiPS. The final mass after calcination was approximately 1.5 g, corresponding to a synthesis yield of around 25 %. 2.2 Synthesis of sandwiched structures (St@NiPS) The synthesis intended to deposit a second silica shell over the nickel phyllosilicate-covered silica nanospheres synthesized as described in the previous section (NiPS). The deposition step was conducted according to the ammonia evaporation method described by Stöber, and the resulting materials were aged for times t = 0, 12, 24, 36, or 48 h (St@NiPS) under hydrolysis at approximately 24 ºC [25,35,49]. An appropriate quantity of calcined NiPS and hexadecylethylenetetramine (HMTA), 1:10 m/m, was dispersed in an ethanol: water (3:2 v:v) solution under ultrasonication. After 1 h, 10 mL of NH3 (aq) (catalyst) and 2 mL of TEOS were slowly added to the system. The pH was adjusted to around 10, after which the system was heated to 60 °C and kept at that temperature for 1 h; after this treatment, a neutral pH was obtained by evaporation of NH3. The material was then stored in an autoclave reactor, where it remained under heating at 70 °C for 4 h. Finally, the gel obtained was aged under agitation in an aqueous medium (hydrolysis) for times t = 12, 24, 36, or 48 h (St@NiPS) at approximately 24 ºC. The gel was not submitted to aqueous treatment for S0@NiPS samples (0 h of hydrolysis time). The material obtained was then centrifuged, washed, dried and calcined at 700 °C (10 °C.min−1) for 4 h under a flow of 50 mL.min−1 of synthetic air. 2.3 Characterization of materials X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed to investigate the crystal structure of the materials. The analyses were conducted at room temperature with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) using a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer [21]. The reducibility of the materials and the quantification of the reducible metal were investigated by thermoprogrammed reduction with H2 (TPR-H2) by reducing 70 mg of catalyst in a flow of 30 mL/min of H2:He 5:95 from 50 to 800 ºC (10 ºC.min−1) [21]. Temperature-programmed methane cracking tests (TPC-CH4) were performed using the same apparatus as the TPR analyses. This analysis enables the qualitative study of methane decomposition temperature, which depends on the catalyst applied, assuming this mimics the limiting step for DRM activity. The analysis was conducted under 50 mL.min−1 and CH4:CO2:He = 25:25:50 from 50 to 800 ºC (10 ºC.min−1) [19]. The measurements of transmission electron microscopy were carried out in direct mode (TEM) and scanning mode (STEM) on a High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope JEOL 2100F-2000kV equipped with an 11-megapixel CCD camera (GATAN Orius) and an energy dispersive spectroscopy detector (EDS) [19,21,51]. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic tests in the DRM under low-temperature conditions were carried out at 700 ºC, GHSV = 60,000 NL.kgcat −1.h−1 and equimolar CH4/CO ratio [19]. The experiments were conducted in a PID reaction unit of ENG & TEC. Further system specifications can be obtained in other works [19,21]. Before testing, the material was reduced in situ under 30 mL.min−1 flow of H2 5.0 and heating rate 10 ºC.min−1 up to 800 ºC. The m/z 28 signal showed no oscillations, and the m/z 44 signal is only a mirror of the m/z 32 signal. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD results The analysis of X-ray diffractograms in Fig. 2, shows that nickel phyllosilicates were formed, as initially proposed. The diffractogram of the S0@NiPS sample exhibited Bragg peaks characteristic of a NiO phase. This phase of nickel exhibits weak interactions with the SiO2 substrate and may contribute to sintering processes, favoring the deactivation of the material. It may also generate particles with more nickel aggregation after the reduction process, if compared to those generated via the decomposition of phyllosilicates. The absence of NiO in the S12, S24, S36, and S48@NiPS samples suggests that the hydrolysis treatment time affects not only the composition of the external silica but also the structures formed by the dispersed nickel, possibly suggesting destruction of the phyllosilicate phase under autoclaving and subsequent restructuring under hydrolysis [52,53]. 3.2 TPR-H2 results Fig. 3 illustrates the TPR profiles of the materials under study. This data indicates that the solids exhibit more than one type of Ni-Si interaction. Additionally, the temperatures and reduction pattern are consistent with the formation of nickel phyllosilicate structures, as indicated by the XRD results. The reduction event centered at 400–500°C is attributed to the decomposition of nickel phyllosilicates 1:1 [54–56]. The second event, observed with a maximum in the region between 600 and 670 °C, was attributed to the reduction of NiPS with a 2:1 structure [54–56]. It was also observed that the hydrolysis time causes a change in the proportion between the two NiPS structures, modifying the ratio between the events. The intense Ni-Si bond in the 2:1 structure suggests that reducing the S24 and S48@NiPS materials will produce smaller, more dispersed nanoparticles on the surface of Stöber spheres. This fact allows us to infer that the hydrolysis process induces an organizational change in the structure, in line with the XRD data, which may impact the activity and stability of the catalysts. Furthermore, the peak morphology is distinctly different for the S0@NiPS material when compared to those that underwent hydrolysis, which is consistent with a different nickel phase (Fig. 2). The data obtained after deconvolution of the peaks and quantification via linear regression are shown in Table 1. All catalysts exhibit similar levels of metal loading. Still, it was observed that the time in hydrolysis may have leached part of the nickel weakly bound to the support, evidenced by the lower value obtained for S24, S36 and S48@NiPS, which corroborates the hypothesis of reorganization of the structure and strengthening of the Si-Ni bond. The behavior of mNi/mcat (%) with hydrolysis time may also suggest that the hydrolysis process contributes to metal lixiviation initially. However, it may contribute to metal redeposition, as indicated by the comparison of S24@NiPS with S48@NiPS in terms of estimated reducible metal content. 3.3 TEM and STEM results Figs. 4 and 5 display the TEM and STEM micrographs, respectively. The elemental mapping experiments, conducted using energy-dispersive spectroscopy with X-rays in scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), are presented in Fig. 5. Table 2 presents the data obtained from statistical analysis. Before microscopy study, the catalysts samples were reduced under 30 mL/min flow of H2:He 5:95 and heating rate 10 ºC/min up to 800 ºC [21]. Micrographs confirm the formation of core-shell structures in all examined cases, with large SiO2 spheres embedded with small nickel nanoparticles (Figs. 4 and 5). The materials chosen for this inspection are related to the best-performing materials (S24@NiPS) and the worst-performing materials (S0@NiPS and S48@NiPS), as discussed in the next section. The data obtained are similar to those obtained by the literature on silica nanospheres and Stöber’s nanospheres [54,57]. Furthermore, it is observed that for the S0@NiPS sample, a significant quantity of bare silica residue is present, indicating that the hydrolysis time is crucial for obtaining a spheroidal structure with homogeneous particle size. S48@NiPS silica nanospheres show a loss of particle size homogeneity, likely due to agglutination given the mean particle size increase. This can be attributed to cross-linking between bare silica and nanospheres, as well as polymerization reactions. On the other hand, NiPS and S24@NiPS presented a profile with a more homogeneous particle size for both Ni particles and silica particles. From Fig. 5, it can be concluded that the second silica deposition was effective in covering the pre-existing silica nanospheres, at least partially. In the particles’ border regions, where the micrographs approximate a cross-sectional view, the presence of a silica layer over the nickel nanoparticles under a silica layer can be inferred ( Fig. 6). This surface decoration is analogous to a second shell for catalysis purposes, as will be discussed further below. The morphological difference between the samples S0, S24 and S48 (Fig. 4) may be attributed to the hydrolysis effect, once all of them were synthetized from the same starting material (NiPS). The hydrolysis time also correlates well with particle size distribution, where shorter hydrolysis time promoted more variance on nickel particle size and longer hydrolysis time promoted more variance on Stöber’s spheres particle size (Fig. 6). This indicates that only the encapsulation step is ineffective for making well-formed homogeneously sized particles, and the reconsolidation of their sizes occurs after the second step under hydrolysis conditions. However, long aging times may lead to undesired effects and polimerize multiple spheres or etch them, diminishing their size distribution homogeneity (Table 2). The particle size of nickel, as indicated by its distribution, is also shown to decrease over hydrolysis time, suggesting a structural rearrangement of the material. 3.4 TPSR-DRM and TPC-CH4 results The TPSR-DRM and TPC-CH4 experiments for NiPS samples are presented in Figs. 8 and 9, along with the corresponding event temperatures listed in Table 3 for the best-performing sample (S24@NiPS) and the worst-performing samples (S0@NiPS and S48@NiPS). Every TPSR-DRM test exhibits standard profiles for the dry reforming of methane, which were verified for all samples, demonstrating the simultaneous consumption of CO2 and CH4, as well as syngas production analogous to that of other nickel-silica catalysts [45,58–60]. The occurrence of the shift reaction is evidenced by the generation of water, especially at temperatures below 650 °C. Higher temperatures reduce H2O production, as expected according to shift reaction thermodynamics [61,62]. These preliminary experiments confirmed that all samples exhibit catalytic activity in the DRM, demonstrating potential for syngas production with a 1:1 ratio at high temperatures. The activation temperature (Table 3) for both tests is the temperature at which events begin to occur, as determined by visual and first derivative inspections. For TPSR-DRM, it represents the first evidence of CO2 and CH4 consumption, as well as H2 and CO evolution. Additionally, TPC represents the consumption of CH4 through C-H bond cleavage. Assuming that the slow stage of DRM is the breakdown of the C-H bond at Ni0 sites, the TPC-CH4 experiments provide insight into both the activity of the materials and the ease of access of CH4 to the active sites [21]. The SiO2 coating increases the TPC activation temperature for S0@NiPS compared to NiPS, a phenomenon observed in similar core@shell materials due to the difficulty in accessing the shell [45]. This effect depends on metal particles occlusion by the second shell; hence, it can explain well the observed surface decoration (Fig. 5 and Fig. 6). However, the aging under hydrolysis decreases the C-H bond cleavage temperature (TPC activation). This may be related to a mechanical confinement effect, destabilizing the transition state more efficiently in S0@NiPS, working as a nanoreactor with dimensions of the space between the Stöber particles and the silica shell. This confinement can act either through a simple mechanical interaction or by populating antibonding orbitals of CH4 or CO2, thereby reducing the energy required to continue the reaction path [34]. It is reported that, under DRM conditions, according to thermodynamic principles, this reaction is primarily responsible for coke generation. However, this carbon has a lower deactivating capacity than others, such as those formed during the Boudouard reaction [19]. In this analysis, higher coke production is observed for the S0 and S24@NiPS ( Table 4), indicating that the confinement effect may significantly influence deactivation. The experiments in the transient temperature regime in the DRM indicate a different trend: the S0 and S48 samples showed lower activation temperatures. In this case, CO2, a molecule with oxidative capacity, is present. A greater number of nickel species were possibly reoxidized to cationic states, favoring combustion mechanisms and enabling the initiation of DRM at lower temperature. Both experiments are consistent with a single hypothesis: the Si-Ni bond in the NiPS and S24@NiPS samples is generally more intense than in the other samples. 3.5 Long term catalytic evaluation The data from long-term experiments in DRM are presented in Fig. 10. The catalytic tests under low temperature conditions show that the hydrolysis time significantly influences the activity of the materials and their resistance to deactivation. The high potential for coking reactions in DRM suggests that this will be the main route of materials’ deactivation [19,63]. At this temperature, the equilibrium condition for only DRM would correspond to around 80 % conversion of CH4 and 80 % conversion of CO2 [19,63]. This indicates that under these conditions, the S24@NiPS reaches near-equilibrium conditions, while others exhibit lower activity. Additionally, CO2 conversion exceeds equilibrium, indicating that it occurs through parallel reactions. The literature reports that the formation of water is typical in DRM through parallel reactions, such as the water-gas shift, thus increasing CO2 conversion compared to CH4 [19,63]. The material with intermediary hydrolysis time, S24@NiPS, exhibited the highest activity during the test. This may be related to the surface decoration, which can be analogized as a shell. According to Li et al. [64], the thickness of the shell is intrinsically linked to the resistance of the catalysts: very thin structures are fragile and can rupture after heat treatment, exposing the particles and favoring agglutinations; very thick ones can hinder the elimination of the carbon generated, promoting the clogging of the pores, sintering of the catalyst nanoparticles and turning active sites inaccessible. The leached silica itself could recombine to form complex structures, thereby preventing access to nickel. The STEM micrographs (Fig. 5) and performance under DRM conditions (Fig. 10) seem to corroborate Li et al. [64] conclusions. The intermediate hydrolysis time improved catalytic performance compared to S0@NiPS and S48@NiPS. These samples were both extremes of no hydrolysis time and, hence, no shell thinning (S0); and 48 h of hydrolysis time and, hence, too much shell deforming, thus producing uneven coverage, either too thick or too thin (S48). This is further corroborated by the intermediate results obtained by the samples S12 and S36@NiPS. Additionally, STEM images reveal that bare silica and asymmetrically size-distributed structures appear more significantly with increasing hydrolysis time, possibly indicating their deformation under these conditions. Such an effect contributes to a loss of activity and a reduction in the protective effect of the core-shell. It is also verified that S24@NiPS showed a higher hydrogen yield, indicating that the conversion increase was directed towards valuable products, and exhibited no signs of deactivation over the 16-hour experiment. This scenario becomes more pronounced when conversion values are taken into account with the reducible nickel mass, as S24@NiPS shows the lowest value among the samples but still presents the best activity (Table 1). It is also known that the presence of H2O in the reaction mixture generates significant problems for confined catalysts, promoting loss of Ni-Si interaction and shell deformation [35,49,54]. It is observed that the S12@NiPS and S24@NiPS samples exhibit higher H₂/CO ratios, which may indicate a lower extent of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (rWGS). [65]. This may have contributed to maintaining activity during the test. A higher H2O(g) content may also contribute to SiO2 corrosion, thereby losing the confinement effect and protection against Cs growth [54]. The TPO experiments are shown in Fig. 11. Table 4 presents the results derived from mathematical analysis. The comparison between the sandwiched structures and NiPS indicates that the shell external to the NiPS silica core reduces conversion rates from CH4 and CO2 to Cs. The lower TPO area value demonstrates this. From this, it can be inferred that the shell, with adequate porosity and thickness, acts as a protective barrier, hindering carbon deposition and its rate of deposition. TPC-CH4 tests (Fig. 8, Table 3) and the TPO (Fig. 11) results corroborate the hypothesis that the carbon cracking reaction is thermodynamically significant to Cs deposition. The trends shown in TPC-CH4 demonstrate that the NiPS sample is more active regarding C-H breaking; this fact, along with the higher TPO area (Table 4), suggests that the carbon generated should originate from this reaction pathway. S0 and S48 present higher C content but have lower CH4 conversion rates. This aligns with the statement made by Li [64]. Thin shells favor sintering of catalysts; thick ones hinder carbon elimination, and a small fraction of coke is enough to clog pores. Additionally, the presence of non-core-shell structures makes some of the material easily deactivated, similar to Ni/SiO₂ catalysts without any special structure other than Ni deposition, which are similar to the NiPS structure, lacking most of the confinement advantages, as demonstrated in this paper. Therefore, it is proposed that the hydrolysis/structuring process is associated with generating more dispersed nanoparticles (Ni-Si bond strengthening), as well as with the textural properties of the shell (thickness, mechanical and thermal resistance, and porosity). As such, the two factors have an optimal point of convergence at 24 h during the hydrolysis step. 4 Conclusions Catalysts based on nickel phyllosilicates were successfully synthesized by the modified Stöber-ammonia evaporation method. This enabled the formation of silica nanospheres that were then successfully coated with a shell through a second step of silica deposition. The layer-analogous silica decoration was tuned by varying the sample aging time in water, and hydrolysis. It was observed that no hydrolysis led to the formation of misshapen and residual silica, and its optimal time (24 h) led to the formation of homogeneously sized spheroidal nanospheres. Longer aqueous treatment times (48 h) deformed the nanospheres, leading to less homogenous particle with poorer catalytic performance. The sample characterization was conducted, permitting inference that the hydrolysis step (i) reorganizes the nickel-silicate network, likely strengthening the Si–Ni interaction and affecting metal reducibility, and (ii) governs the final size homogeneity, porosity, and integrity of the core@shell architecture. These structural modifications directly impacted the accessibility of active sites, coke resistance, and catalytic activity. Among the evaluated materials, S24@NiPS presented higher activity and selectivity. The activity order observed was S24@NiPS > S12@NiPS > NiPS > S36@NiPS > S48@NiPS > S0@NiPS. This indicates that both short and long hydrolysis times produce unwanted effects, which can be explained by the framework of Li et al. [61] regarding shell thickness, leading to the emergence of an optimal hydrolysis type. These results suggest that post-synthetic hydrolysis routes can modulate silica shell design to create robust DRM catalysts based on non-noble metals. The principles established here can contribute to the rational design of next-generation materials for CO₂ valorization and methane upgrading in industrial settings. coredata.dc:description: A new method for synthesis of catalysts with core@shell architecture has been developed for syngas production via dry reforming of methane (DRM). This route is based on the confinement of Stöber particles (silica nanospheres) by nickel phyllosilicates and a layer-analogous decoration made of SiO2 (shell). Dry reforming catalysts based on non-noble metals suffer from deactivation via sintering and coke formation. Core@shell structures offer a strategy to enhance stability and control metal dispersion. In this work, the Stöber particles were obtained and then nickel phyllosilicate was synthetized over them (NiPS); silica was deposited on the resulting material producing a decorated material (S0@NiPS) and the effect of its aging under hydrolysis conditions for 12, 24, 36 and 48 h was evaluated (S12, S24, S36 and S48@NiPS). It was possible to demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed structures, with reagent conversion above 90 %, good yield to syngas and no signs of deactivation in the catalytic test at 700°C (coking condition), for the S24@NiPS sample (reducible nickel content 8 % w/w). The superior activity of S24@NiPS is attributed to optimal Ni dispersion and shell structure, balancing accessibility and confinement. The order of activity obtained was: S24@NiPS > S12@NiPS > NiPS > S36@NiPS > S48@NiPS > S0@NiPS. The materials were characterized by XRD, TPR-H2, TPO-O2, TEM, EDS and TPSR-DRM. The modification of the hydrolysis time changed the properties of the catalysts: the shortest and longest times generated the less active catalysts. These findings offer a route to a coke-resistant catalysts for CO₂ valorization and methane upgrading.
